item.title: How-To Calibrate American Options Really Fast
item.author: oleksandr@gituliar.net (Oleksandr Gituliar)
item.description: In this post, you will learn how to calibrate American options in C++ with modern methods and open-source tools, so that calibration will be really fast with source code open to review. Source code itself is located in gituliar/tastyhedge repo on GitHub, which you can build and run it on Linux or Windows. This repo also contains all necessary market data to reproduce discussed examples. Calibration is a process of fitting parameters of the model to the market data.

item.title: Pricing Americans with Finite-Difference
item.author: oleksandr@gituliar.net (Oleksandr Gituliar)
item.description: In my previous post Pricing Derivatives on a Budget I discussed performance of the finite-difference algorithm for pricing American options on CPU vs GPU. Since then, people have asked to elaborate on the pricing algorithm itself. Hence, this post is dedicated to the Finite-Difference Method. C++ is a great language to implement a finite-difference pricer on CPU and GPU. You’ll find full source code from the previous post on GitHub in gituliar/kwinto-cuda repo.

item.title: Pricing Derivatives on a Budget
item.author: oleksandr@gituliar.net (Oleksandr Gituliar)
item.description: After five years working as a quant, I can tell that the wast majority of derivative pricing in the financial industry is done on CPU. This is easily explained by two facts: (1) no GPU was available when banks started developing their pricing analytics in 90’s; and (2) banking is a conservative sector, slow to upgrade its technical stack. American Options. In this post, I benchmark pricing of American Options on GPU.

item.title: Memory Layout of std::string
item.author: oleksandr@gituliar.net (Oleksandr Gituliar)
item.description: For a professional C++ developer, it’s important to understand memory organization of the data structures, especially when it comes to the containers from the C++ Standard Library. In this post of Tasty C++ series we’ll look inside of std::string, so that you can more effectively work with C++ strings and take advantage and avoid pitfalls of the C++ Standard Library you are using. In C++ Standard Library, std::string is one of the three contiguous containers (together with std::array and std::vector).
